topic.name: Chronological Bible Narrative
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Chronological Bible Narrative in Bible & Theology

objectives.objective_text: Identify Joshua as the new leader after Moses.
Name Rahab as the woman who helped the spies.
Identify God as the maker of the world and the first family (Adam and Eve).
Name Cain and Abel as the first brothers.
Identify Elijah as the prophet who called down fire.
Name Jonah as the prophet who was swallowed by a big fish.
Identify the Holy Spirit as the helper Jesus sent.
Name Peter and Paul as men who told the world about Jesus.
Identify Daniel in the lions' den.
Name Queen Esther who saved her people.
Identify Moses as the baby in the basket who became a leader.
Name the Red Sea crossing as God's great rescue.
Identify Samson as the strong man and Gideon as the brave leader.
Name the Judges as helpers God sent when the people were in trouble.
Identify the manger, the cross, and the empty tomb.
Name the disciples who followed Jesus.
Identify Abraham as the man who believed God's promise.
Name Isaac, Jacob, and Joseph as the fathers of Israel.
Identify Saul as the first king and David as the best king.
Name Solomon as the king who built God's house (Temple).
Recall that the people promised to serve the Lord.
Recall that sin made the world a sad and hard place.
Recall that the kingdom split into two parts: North and South.
Observe that bad kings led people away from God.
Recall that the first church shared their food and money.
Observe how the church grew from a few people to many.
Recall that the people came back to build the walls of Jerusalem.
Observe that God was with them even when they were far from home.
Recall the Ten Commandments as God's good rules.
Observe how God fed the people with manna in the desert.
Recall that the people kept forgetting God.
Observe that God always forgave them when they prayed.
Recall that God changed Jacob's name to Israel.
Recall that David wrote songs to God (Psalms).
Retell the story of the walls of Jericho falling down.
Summarize the crossing of the Jordan River on dry ground.
Explain why Achan's sin caused the whole nation to lose a battle.
Explain the significance of the Cities of Refuge.
Perform research on the archaeological evidence for the conquest of Jericho/Ai.
Retell the story of Noah and the Ark using pictures or toys.
Summarize the sequence of events: Creation, Fall, Cain/Abel, Flood, Babel.
Explain why God sent the Flood (judgment on wickedness).
Categorize the sons of Noah (Shem, Ham, Japheth) as the fathers of nations.
Explain the significance of the 'Proto-evangelium' (Gen 3:15) in the early narrative.
Defend the historicity of Adam and the Flood against mythical interpretations.
Summarize the contest on Mount Carmel with the prophets of Baal.
Explain why the kingdom divided (Rehoboam's foolishness).
Categorize prophets by who they spoke to (Israel, Judah, or other nations).
Explain the reforms of Hezekiah and Josiah.
Defend the justice of the Exile based on the warnings of Deuteronomy.
Produce a study on the 'Day of the Lord' theme in the prophets.
Summarize the story of Pentecost and the tongues of fire.
Explain how Saul (bad) became Paul (good).
Explain the role of persecution in spreading the Gospel.
Perform research on the martyrdom of the Apostles.
Summarize the story of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego.
Explain what 'Exile' means (being sent away).
Explain the problem of the people's hearts remaining hard even after the return.
Defend the faithfulness of God in preserving the Davidic line during the Exile.
Summarize the ten plagues and why God sent them (to show He is the true God).
Explain the meaning of the Passover meal.
Categorize the furniture in the Tabernacle (Ark, Table, Lampstand).
Explain the Holiness Code in Leviticus (God dwelling among His people).
Defend the Mosaic Law as a reflection of God's character, not arbitrary rules.
Produce an essay on the Typology of the Exodus as a pattern for salvation.
Summarize the cycle of Judges: Sin, Slavery, Supplication, Salvation.
Explain why Gideon used only 300 men.
Categorize the enemies of Israel (Philistines, Midianites, Moabites).
Explain the role of the 'Kinsman-Redeemer' in the book of Ruth (set during Judges).
Defend the sovereignty of God in using flawed leaders.
Produce a thematic study on 'Apostasy' using the book of Judges.
Retell a parable like the Lost Sheep or Good Samaritan.
Express that Jesus is God who became a man.
Summarize the baptism and temptation of Jesus.
Explain the meaning of the 'Incarnation' (God putting on flesh).
Categorize Jesus' ministry into teaching, healing, and suffering.
Explain the significance of the Ascension for the church today.
Defend the miracles of Jesus against naturalistic skepticism.
Produce an essay on how Jesus fulfills the three offices: Prophet, Priest, King.
Retell the story of Joseph's coat and his journey to Egypt.
Summarize the call of Abraham and his journey to Canaan.
Explain how Jacob tricked Esau but later learned to trust God.
Trace the movement of God's people from Ur to Canaan to Egypt.
Explain the concept of Election through the choice of Isaac over Ishmael, and Jacob over Esau.
Defend the providence of God in preserving the messianic line through famine and conflict.
Retell the story of David and Goliath.
Summarize how David was chosen (heart vs. outward appearance).
Explain why Saul lost the kingdom.
Explain the consequences of David's sin with Bathsheba on his family.
Perform research on the historical wealth and trade of Solomon's kingdom.
Compare the spies who trusted God (Joshua/Caleb) with those who didn't.
Apply the phrase 'As for me and my house, we will serve the Lord.'
Analyze the military strategy and divine intervention in the conquest campaigns.
Interpret the ethical difficulty of the Canaanite conquest (God's judgment on sin).
Connect the allotment of the land to God fulfilling His promise to Abraham.
Compare the world before the Flood with the world after.
Analyze the downward spiral of sin from the Garden to Babel.
Interpret the 'Table of Nations' in Genesis 10 as the origin of diverse cultures.
Connect the Tower of Babel judgment to the Great Commission (reversing the confusion).
Compare the Northern Kingdom (Israel) and the Southern Kingdom (Judah).
Analyze the sin of Jeroboam (golden calves) and its lasting effect.
Interpret the role of the prophet as a covenant lawyer prosecuting the nation.
Connect the fall of Samaria (722 BC) to the Assyrian empire.
Compare the church in Jerusalem with the missionary journeys of Paul.
Apply the boldness of the apostles to sharing faith today.
Analyze the conflict regarding Gentiles and the Law (Acts 15).
Interpret the significance of the destruction of the Temple in AD 70.
Connect the missionary journeys to the geography of the Roman Empire.
Compare the rebuilding of the Temple (Ezra) with the rebuilding of the Wall (Nehemiah).
Apply Nehemiah's prayer and hard work to a personal task.
Analyze the providence of God in the book of Esther (where God is not named).
Interpret the vision of the Valley of Dry Bones in Ezekiel.
Connect the decree of Cyrus to the prophecy of Jeremiah (70 years).
Compare the Golden Calf incident with true worship.
Analyze the hardening of Pharaoh's heart.
Interpret the symbolism of the Tabernacle and the High Priest's garments.
Connect the rebellion at Kadesh Barnea to the 40 years of wandering.
Compare Deborah (a good judge) with Samson (a flawed judge).
Analyze the refrain 'In those days there was no king in Israel.'
Interpret the story of Jephthah's vow.
Connect the moral decline in Judges to the need for a righteous King.
Compare the responses of the Pharisees vs. the sinners to Jesus.
Analyze the 'I Am' statements in the Gospel of John.
Interpret the Sermon on the Mount as the ethic of the Kingdom.
Connect the Transfiguration to the glory of God in the OT.
Compare the faith of Abraham with the mistakes he made (like lying about Sarah).
Analyze the testing of Abraham's faith in Genesis 22 (The Binding of Isaac).
Interpret Joseph's statement: 'You meant it for evil, but God meant it for good.'
Connect the twelve sons of Jacob to the Twelve Tribes of Israel.
Compare David's repentance (Psalm 51) with Saul's excuses.
Apply lessons from Solomon's wisdom and his foolishness (many wives).
Analyze the Davidic Covenant (2 Samuel 7).
Interpret the political and spiritual consolidation of Jerusalem.
Connect Solomon's Temple dedication prayer to God's global purpose.
Evaluate the incompleteness of the conquest and its future consequences.
Evaluate different interpretations of the 'Sons of God' in Genesis 6.
Evaluate the geopolitical situation involving Assyria, Babylon, and Egypt.
Evaluate the transition from Jewish sect to global religion.
Evaluate the spiritual condition of the post-exilic community through Malachi.
Evaluate the date of the Exodus (Early vs. Late date theories).
Evaluate the role of women in the book of Judges.
Evaluate the hypostatic union (fully God, fully man) and why it matters.
Evaluate the cultural context of patriarchal customs (covenants, birthrights, marriage).
Evaluate the tension between the theocracy and the monarchy.
Construct a theological defense of Holy War in the OT context.
Synthesize the theme of 'Rest' in Joshua with Hebrews 4.
Construct a timeline of Primeval History using biblical genealogies.
Construct a timeline of the kings and the prophets who ministered to them.
Construct a map of the spread of Christianity in the first century.
Synthesize the main themes of the Apostolic preaching (Kerygma).
Construct a historical overview of the Persian Empire's role in biblical history.
Synthesize the 'already/not yet' nature of the restoration in the OT.
Construct a map of the likely route of the Exodus.
Construct a chart tracking the spiraling depravity from Othniel to Samson.
Construct a harmony of the Gospels for the Passion Week.
Construct a family tree of the Patriarchs including wives and key descendants.
Synthesize the Abrahamic Covenant with the rest of redemptive history.
Construct a profile of the 'Messianic King' based on the United Monarchy.
Synthesize the rise and peak of Israel's history as a type of the Kingdom of God.
Synthesize the theology of creation and judgment found in Genesis 1-11.
